Wait, let me double-check that math. She starts with $10, spends N, so her remaining money is 10 - N. John receives 3N, which he gives to Emily? So if Emily decides to give all her money, say N = 10, then she would get back 30 dollars from John. But wait, does she have only the $10? Or can she use the future payment? The question says she receives $10 from the study group. So it's likely that she has to give N from her own money. So if she gives all $10, then she'd get 3*10 = $30 back, making her net gain 20 dollars.

But is this a one-time deal? The question doesn't specify the number of rounds, but since it's an experiment, maybe it's just once. If it's only one time, giving all would be good because she's getting more than what she's losing.

However, if there are multiple opportunities, then maybe she shouldn't give everything to maximize future gains, but the question doesn't mention that. So I think in this case, since it's a single interaction, Emily should give as much as possible to maximize her immediate gain.

But wait, giving more than what she has might be an issue if she can't afford it, but the problem doesn't specify any constraints on how much she can give. So theoretically, she could give all $10 and get tripled for a net gain of 20.

Alternatively, maybe the question is trickier because she knows that John will respond similarly. But since we're told to assume it's a one-time interaction unless specified otherwise, I think she should maximize her gain by giving as much as possible.
